{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3487097,"name":"","username":"BoraxNumber8","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/boraxnumber8/{size}/216473_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T00:20:46.852Z","cooked":"

I’ve had a lot of issues figuring out how to set up the new radios, but today I finally got it all set up, utilizing 6GHz. I’m posting a guide here to make it easier for other teams.

For the 6GHz setup, you will need two VH-109 radios. One will be on the robot (hereafter known as Robot Radio), and one connected to your driver station computer (hereafter known as Access Point Radio). Vivid Hosting’s documentation for these does talk about wiring and mounting, and I found that to be pretty clear. However, their docs for configuring the radio were not clear to me.

Beginning Setup (need to do this for both radios)

  1. Attach an Ethernet cable from your laptop to the DS port on the radio.
  2. Install and launch Vivid Hosting’s Network Assistant Tool (found in their documentation)
  3. In the Network Assistant Tool, select Ethernet from the dropdown, then click Configure
  4. After it tells you that the configuration is successful, click Ok
  5. Click on Check Radio Status, then click Ok
  6. Click Yes to open the configuration page for the radio

Robot Radio Setup

  1. Power your Robot Radio either from your PDH, or temporarily from West Coast Products’ PoE Wall Adaptor (WCP-0561)
  2. Select Robot Radio mode
  3. Add your team number
  4. Optionally, add a suffix to the network name
  5. Set a WPA key. This is the password for your network.
  6. Click Configure. The green Sys light will go solid, and will start blinking again when the configuration has been received.
  7. Upgrade your firmware, if necessary.

There are two versions of the upgrade, one where you upgrade from earlier than 1.2.x versions, and one where you upgrade from being on 1.2.x versions. When you upgrade your firmware, the radio will reboot several times. When the Sys light is blinking slowly, the upgrade is complete.

  1. After this setup is complete, wire your Robot Radio to the robot, making sure you’re powering it and that it has an Ethernet connection to the roboRIO.

Access Point Radio Setup

  1. Make sure your Access Point Radio is being powered using the PoE Wall Adaptor (this is how it will be powered while using it to drive your robot)
  2. Select Access Point mode
  3. Add your team number
  4. Optionally, add a suffix to the network name

NOTE: If you chose to add a suffix to the Robot Radio, you will need to set the suffix to the same thing on the Access Point Radio

  1. Set a WPA key. This needs to be the same password that you set up for the Robot Radio.
  2. Optionally, choose a specific WiFi channel. If you leave this blank, it will automatically choose the channel, and presumably do the thing that most devices do and hop between channels.
  3. Upgrade your firmware, if necessary.

Unless you have more than one robot, do not select the Access Point variant of the firmware. Use the Robot Radio variant.

Driver Station Laptop Setup

  1. Windows key + R
  2. Type ncpa.cpl to go to your Network Connections
  3. Right click on Ethernet, then click Properties
  4. Double click Internet Protocol Version 4
  5. Use the following IP address: 10.TE.AM.5, where TE.AM is your team number
  6. Use the following subnet mask: 255.255.255.0
  7. Leave your default gateway blank, and leave your DNS blank

Once both of your radios are fully set up, navigate back to the config page for your Access Point Radio. I have found that when I shut off the Access Point Radio, I need to re-enter the network config information. Make sure that you can see the connection to the Robot Radio (another section will appear on the config page). Open FRC Driver Station on your laptop. It will take 20-30 seconds for you to see communication with the robot.

That should be everything! Feel free to ask me any questions, I’m happy to re-explain anything that doesn’t make sense.

Is there any way to do this with out 2 radios

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T18:46:53.594Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":293,"readers_count":292,"score":98.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482589,"topic_slug":"vivid-hosting-radio-setup-guide","display_username":"Ada","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/vivid-hosting-radio-setup-guide/482589/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488273,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T18:52:27.591Z","cooked":"

You can…however it’s not recommended.

The radios run warm, and as they heat up they throttle 2.4GHz performance and even disconnect.

As a brand new team this might be acceptable due to cost in the short term, but I would plan for future seasons purchasing more radios, as a backup to your primary radio, and to practice more reliably with.

To turn on the 2.4GHz, toggle the dip switch on the back of the radio for 2.4GHz.

This will allow you to connect directly wirelessly with most laptops. But again if you get disconnects during practice sessions, or not great range, this is likely the cause and the only remedy is a 2ed radio so you can use 6GHz.

BoraxNumber8:

10.TE.AM.4

.4 is used for the field router.

Do not use .4
